New York–based artist, curator, and educator Javier Tèllez-Villar, who has lived and worked in New York City since 1991, has been nominated for a Pulitzer Prize for his work on architecture. Tèllez-Villar’s Architectural Performance series, which assembles disparate architectural and design pieces to form a large-scale art installation, has been nominated for nine other prizes, including the National Book Award in Architecture and Design, the Pulitzer Prize in Art, and the Alan Eller Award in Art. He will be awarded the Pulitzer Prize for Architecture and Design sometime this month, along with a $50,000 prize.Tèllez-Villar’s work will be included in the exhibition “The Architecture of Life” curated by David Kordansky at the Cooper-Hewitt, in partnership with the St. Louis Art Museum, at the Museum of Modern Art, and at the Museum of Modern Art.
